danish_publication: Imellem Tjæreborg og Trasborg til nord for Vadgård og inde i Bondegårds mark ligger Hellegård banke og Borregård banke. Her har ligget to borge. Fjenderne anfaldt manden på den sidste og stak ham ihjel, te indvoldene væltede ud. Så sagde han: "Nu er det bedst, lille börn, I gjör ende på det." Hans kone hed Buurgier, og hun fulgte dem udenfor, da de rejste af. Da de kom ud, törrede de deres blodige dolke af i hendes forklæde. Så tog de vejen efter Hellegård. De kom til nogle hyrder, og de flygtede. Manden flygtede for dem ud i en stendynge. "Er ræven her inde?" råbte de, stak ind med deres spyd og stak ham ihjel. Sådan faldt Hellegård, og bakken har navn efter ham endnu.
english_publication: Between Tjærborg and Træsborg north of Vadgård and in Bondegård’s field lie Hellegård hill and Borregård hill. There used to be two forts there. The enemies attacked the man at the last one and stabbed him to death until his innards ran out. Then he said: “Now it's best, little children, that you make an end of it.” His wife was called Buurgier, and she followed them outside when they left. When they came out, they wiped off their bloody daggers in her apron. Then they took the road towards Hellegård. They came across some shepherds who fled. The farmer fled from them too out into a stone pile. “Is the fox in here?” they yelled, and stuck their spears into the pile and stabbed him to death. That’s how Hellegård fell, and the hill is named after him even now.
